org.fileprocessor

Class DefaultLineProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.fileprocessor.DefaultLineProcessor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    LineProcessor

    public class DefaultLineProcessor
extends java.lang.Object
implements LineProcessor
    Default Implementation of the @link org.fileprocessor.LineProcessor interface that calculates several simple stats: word count, line count, average number of letters per word (to one decimal place) and most common letter.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String LETTER_PER_WORD
      Key for average number of letters per word.
      static java.lang.String LINES
      Key for the total number of number of lines in the file.
      static java.lang.String MOST_COMMON_LETTER
      Key for the most common letter processed so far.
      static java.lang.String WORDS
      Key for the total number of number of words in the file.

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DefaultLineProcessor() 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.util.List<java.lang.String> getKeyNames()
      Returns a list of "tags" (keys in a Map) that can be used by the developer of a class implementing this interface to give a name to whatever stats/values the Processor is calculating.
      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getKVForProcessedLines()
      Return a map where the key is the stat name and the value is the actual value of the calculated stat over the processed lines.
      java.lang.String printProcessedLines()
      Pretty prints the desired statistics
      void process(java.lang.String line)
      Calculates statistics from the provided line and accumulates results in internal data structures.

      • MOST_COMMON_LETTER

        public static final java.lang.String MOST_COMMON_LETTER
        Key for the most common letter processed so far. If two are equal, returns the firs one by lexicographic order.
        See Also:
